content.question: Time Angular speed Direction of rotation <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> <math alttext="3 radians per second " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math> Unknown <math alttext="t equals 10 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> <math alttext="2 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math> Counterclockwise A student is provided with the data shown in the table for the angular speed of a wheel. Does the student have enough information to calculate the average angular acceleration of the wheel? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the average angular acceleration only depends on the change in angular speed and the time.
Yes, because the angular acceleration only depends on the final values of the angular speed and the time.
No, because the angular displacement needs to be known along with change in angular speed and time.
No, because the initial direction of rotation must be known to calculate the change in the angular velocity.

content.answer: No, because the initial direction of rotation must be known to calculate the change in the angular velocity.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
